sutras.name: Ekadhikena Purvena
sutras.translation: By one more than the previous one
sutras.objective: Master instant squaring of numbers ending in 5
sutras.why_learn: Your go-to method for squaring numbers ending in 5 (15², 25²...95²). Essential for quick area calculations, price estimates with 5-cent increments, and geometry. Trains pattern recognition and builds confidence that complex calculations have elegant solutions. Answer '85²' in under 2 seconds (7225) - a genuine competitive advantage.
rule: Multiply by one more than itself
sutras.mini_game: Square Dash - combo multipliers for speed

sutras.name: Nikhilam Navatascaramam Dasataḥ
sutras.translation: All from 9 and the last from 10
sutras.objective: Multiply numbers near bases (10, 100, 1000) using complements
sutras.why_learn: Ideal for multiplying numbers close to 10, 100, or 1000 (like 97×96, 998×994). Critical for financial calculations with near-round numbers, engineering estimates, and competitive math. Builds mental agility with complements and base arithmetic. In retail pricing (£98×103 items), this saves minutes daily. The complement thinking trains your brain for advanced problem decomposition.
sutras.mini_game: Near-Base Rush - match numbers to bases

sutras.name: Urdhva-Tiryagbhyam
sutras.objective: Master universal multiplication through crosswise pattern
sutras.why_learn: The UNIVERSAL multiplication method that works for ANY numbers - from 12×13 to 9876×5432. While other sutras are specialized, this is your Swiss Army knife. Essential for competitive exams, engineering calculations, and anywhere calculators aren't available. Trains spatial visualization as you mentally draw crosswise patterns. Once mastered, you'll never use traditional long multiplication again. It's the most versatile technique in the entire Vedic arsenal.

sutras.name: Paravartya Yojayet
sutras.translation: Transpose and apply / Transpose and adjust
sutras.why_learn: Your secret weapon for complex divisions without long division. Especially powerful when divisor is near a base (dividing by 98, 997, etc.). Used in financial rate calculations, unit conversions, and data normalization. Builds algebraic thinking by teaching you to manipulate equations mentally. When dividing large datasets by constants (like 103), this method is 5x faster than calculators.

sutras.name: Sunyam Samyasamuccaye
sutras.translation: When the sum is the same, that sum is zero
sutras.objective: Solve special algebraic equations where sums cancel
sutras.why_learn: Elite technique for equations where coefficient sums match on both sides (like 3x+5=5x+3). Rare but devastating when applicable - solves in one mental step what normally takes 5 written steps. Critical in advanced algebra, competitive math olympiads, and physics formula manipulation. Trains you to spot hidden symmetries in equations. When it works, you look like a mathematical genius.
rule: Check if sum of coefficients on both sides equals
If equal, solution is zero or special value

sutras.name: Anurupyena
sutras.why_learn: Master of ratio and proportion problems - recipes, currency conversion, scaling blueprints, mixing chemicals. When quantities scale proportionally (double recipe, half the fabric), this makes calculations instant. Essential for cooking, construction, photography ratios, and business forecasting. Builds intuition for linear relationships. Instead of setting up formal proportion equations, you see the scale factor instantly.

sutras.name: Sankalana-Vyavakalanabhyam
sutras.why_learn: The go-to method for solving pairs of equations (x+y=10, x-y=2). Crucial in physics (two forces), economics (supply-demand), chemistry (mixture problems), and competitive math. Instead of substitution's multiple steps, this gives direct answers. Trains systematic problem decomposition. When you have two unknowns and two equations, this is your first weapon - fast, reliable, elegant.
rule: Add equations to eliminate one variable

sutras.name: Purna-Apurnabhyam
sutras.objective: Use completion method for calculations near round numbers
sutras.why_learn: When numbers are 'almost complete' to round values (299, 4998), this completes them mentally for easier computation. Perfect for shopping totals ($299→$300-$1), project estimates (4950 units→5000-50), and mental approximations. Trains you to see numbers as 'base plus adjustment' rather than absolute values. Critical skill for rapid mental arithmetic in business meetings where precise estimates must be instant.
rule: Complete number to next round value
sutras.mini_game: Complete & Adjust - fill to round numbers

sutras.name: Calana-Kalanabhyam
sutras.objective: Apply differential/sequential techniques for special patterns
sutras.why_learn: Advanced technique for finding patterns in sequences, rate problems, and calculus-adjacent arithmetic. When conventional algebra fails, this explores the 'motion' between numbers. Essential for series summations, polynomial evaluations, and recursive patterns. Used in algorithm optimization and competitive programming. Trains differential thinking - instead of 'what is it?', asking 'how does it change?' Prepares mind for calculus concepts.

sutras.name: Yavadunam
sutras.why_learn: Sister technique to Nikhilam but focuses on deficiency pattern. Excellent for numbers just below bases (89×87, 996×994). Particularly powerful in financial calculations with discount percentages (15% off → 85% pricing). Reinforces complement thinking from multiple angles. When Nikhilam feels awkward, this provides the alternative perspective that clicks.

sutras.name: Vyastisamastih
sutras.objective: Break complex problems into parts while maintaining whole-view
sutras.why_learn: Meta-technique for decomposing intimidating problems into manageable chunks while tracking the big picture. Critical for multi-step word problems, project planning, budget allocation, and strategic thinking. When a calculation has 'too many moving parts,' this systematizes the breakdown. Builds project management mindset - seeing both forest and trees. Used in advanced algebra factorization and integral calculus setup.

sutras.name: Sesanyankena Caramena
sutras.translation: The remainders and the last by the last
sutras.objective: Master remainder patterns in division and modular arithmetic
sutras.why_learn: Elite technique for divisibility tests, modular arithmetic, and cryptography foundations. When checking if 13 divides 12,345, this is faster than division. Essential for computer science (hash functions), number theory competitions, and calendar calculations (day of week for any date). Builds pattern recognition in remainders - seeing cycles invisible to others. Foundation skill for advanced mathematics.

sutras.name: Sopaantyadvayamantyam
sutras.translation: The ultimate and twice the penultimate
sutras.objective: Apply ultimate-penultimate pattern in special multiplications
sutras.why_learn: Specialized for numbers where pattern between last two digits creates shortcut (like 12×18 where 2+8=10). Perfect for certain multiplication families and polynomial evaluations. Trains you to spot hidden relationships between digit positions. While narrow in application, when it fits, it's spectacular - solving in seconds what looks complex. Builds awareness that 'where digits sit' matters as much as 'what they are.'

sutras.name: Ekanyunena Purvena
sutras.translation: By one less than the previous one
sutras.objective: Master fraction-to-decimal conversion using one-less pattern
sutras.why_learn: Your secret weapon for converting fractions like 1/9, 1/99, 1/999 to decimals instantly (0.111..., 0.0101..., 0.001001...). Critical for percentage calculations, decimal conversions in finance, and pattern-based estimation. Sister technique to Sutra 1 (one MORE) - together they bookend the pattern spectrum. Builds deep understanding of decimal place value and recurring decimals.
rule: Use one less (8) as numerator pattern

sutras.name: Gunitasamuchyah
sutras.translation: The product of sum is same (product-sum relationships)
sutras.objective: Exploit product-sum equality patterns in special equations
sutras.why_learn: Advanced algebraic technique for equations where products equal sums (like ab=a+b). Rare occurrence but when spotted, reduces complex algebra to instant solution. Used in Diophantine equations, competitive math olympiads, and theoretical physics symmetry problems. Trains you to recognize deep structural patterns others miss. When standard algebraic manipulation fails, this reveals the elegant backdoor.
rule: Check if product of terms equals their sum

sutras.name: Gunakasamuchyah
sutras.translation: The factors of sum are the same (factor-sum relationships)
sutras.why_learn: Final and most abstract sutra - recognizes when factors share sum properties. Used in advanced factorization, cryptography (factoring large numbers), and combinatorics. While applications are specialized, it completes the Vedic system's philosophy: all relationships can be seen as patterns. Trains highest-level mathematical abstraction. Completing all 16 sutras means you see mathematics as an interconnected web of patterns, not isolated rules.
